document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q97.F: There is no Utopia. Certainly not in the Army. Since it is to a certain extent democratic there is a certain amount of ball pulling. I think there is a great deal of inefficiency, but I haven't been in long enough to express my views with confidence. What amazes me is how such an inefficient outfit in training.
S64.Q97.C_1: can do so well in actual combat. I have no doubt in victory, but goddamit, you boys of at on the ball and make it soon
S64.Q97.Full: There is no Utopia. Certainly not in the Army. Since it is to a certain extent democratic there is a certain amount of ball pulling. I think there is a great deal of inefficiency, but I haven't been in long enough to express my views with confidence. What amazes me is how such an inefficient outfit in training. can do so well in actual combat. I have no doubt in victory, but goddamit, you boys of at on the ball and make it soon

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q97.F: My premises of war are - War is due to hatred. Hatred is due to want. Want is due to monopoly. Monopoly is due to avarice. Avarice is due to sloth. [paragraph] People have become lazy the world over along with other selfish and ambitious and lustful desires. These
S64.Q97.C_1: to these weaknesses the cycle of economics -- to politics -- to domination -- to large scale hold up has revolved once more. Future wars like the past are inevitable. Material and lives will be consumed until man realizes the fact wholesale murder and robbery and hatred cannot and will not insubordinate and completely defeat an enemy. If it would then our own national problems would be solved. I would suggest that a copy of the commandments should be handed to each congressman, officer and civilian, a new testament to each soldier and W.A.C.
S64.Q97.Full: My premises of war are - War is due to hatred. Hatred is due to want. Want is due to monopoly. Monopoly is due to avarice. Avarice is due to sloth. [paragraph] People have become lazy the world over along with other selfish and ambitious and lustful desires. These  to these weaknesses the cycle of economics -- to politics -- to domination -- to large scale hold up has revolved once more. Future wars like the past are inevitable. Material and lives will be consumed until man realizes the fact wholesale murder and robbery and hatred cannot and will not insubordinate and completely defeat an enemy. If it would then our own national problems would be solved. I would suggest that a copy of the commandments should be handed to each congressman, officer and civilian, a new testament to each soldier and W.A.C.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: This idea of singing in ranks while marching, yet if you say one word they hop on our backs. I always understood that when marching we were at attention. If we can't talk then we shouldn't be allowed to sing. (see I. D. R.) Also this idea of getting up in the early hours of morn to go to school, yet half of our school hours are devoted to cleaning up the classroom. I don't know maybe I'm wrong.
S64.Q97.C_1: Calisthenics are too brisk for such hot days, they should cut most of these mass drills and concentrate more on games if they want us to function as a team. [paragraph] Officers in the air corps are not of the best material (this excludes flying officers) but most of these administration officers seem ready to take there places in home for the feeble minded. Never seen so many officers that are so sternly against enlisted men.
S64.Q97.Full: This idea of singing in ranks while marching, yet if you say one word they hop on our backs. I always understood that when marching we were at attention. If we can't talk then we shouldn't be allowed to sing. (see I. D. R.) Also this idea of getting up in the early hours of morn to go to school, yet half of our school hours are devoted to cleaning up the classroom. I don't know maybe I'm wrong. Calisthenics are too brisk for such hot days, they should cut most of these mass drills and concentrate more on games if they want us to function as a team. [paragraph] Officers in the air corps are not of the best material (this excludes flying officers) but most of these administration officers seem ready to take there places in home for the feeble minded. Never seen so many officers that are so sternly against enlisted men.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: I think I could do more on the outside than in the army they do too much hurrying and get there then wait my job is fairly important but I am needed at home on the farm witch is very inportant industry now. My father is a cripple and has a large farm to care for witch ordinarily took 3 men he lost to do as best he can when I see these draft dodgers on the loose I could almost crack. We a lot [/unclear] [unclear] of heads. I have 2 brothers in the service
S64.Q97.C_1: that have children and a lot of men that are out home now. I volunteered for one year service and I have been in almost 3 years. 34 months. I do not have the rating I deserve. Men here have these ratings given too them here in the quartermaster - and then the ordnance Co. I sweated out 2 years for a Pfc. here they get it in 2 mo. buck sargents that don't know there right from there left. I think the ratings should be given acording to service & ability the officers are all rookies they have 6 to 8 mo. service they don't know the score. I have always been under mostly west point officers and it is how to get a head but you knew your stuff when you did.
S64.Q97.Full: I think I could do more on the outside than in the army they do too much hurrying and get there then wait my job is fairly important but I am needed at home on the farm witch is very inportant industry now. My father is a cripple and has a large farm to care for witch ordinarily took 3 men he lost to do as best he can when I see these draft dodgers on the loose I could almost crack. We a lot [/unclear] [unclear] of heads. I have 2 brothers in the service that have children and a lot of men that are out home now. I volunteered for one year service and I have been in almost 3 years. 34 months. I do not have the rating I deserve. Men here have these ratings given too them here in the quartermaster - and then the ordnance Co. I sweated out 2 years for a Pfc. here they get it in 2 mo. buck sargents that don't know there right from there left. I think the ratings should be given acording to service & ability the officers are all rookies they have 6 to 8 mo. service they don't know the score. I have always been under mostly west point officers and it is how to get a head but you knew your stuff when you did.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: Well I'm the kind of a guy that like this sort of life of moving around quite a bit and being outside all the time. There are a few things that the army does that are silly. For one they waste to much time getting things done. They don't get things organized
S64.Q97.C_1: like they should have. The food problem is very poorly run here. We stand in line for an hour or more to get a skimpy meal sometimes. There is mess halls close to us but we have to eat at the farthest one and that takes up half our time. They don't pay us regular as they should & they don't let us out of camp enough to let us enjoy a little freedom once in a while. The way things are run mow it seems we are like prisoners. We march to & from chow & to & from the toilets. In fact we march every place. The Non Coms [Noncommissioned officers] & C.O. [Commanding Officer] are plenty swell here but don't give us a chance to do anything we want to do. The fellows here ough [ought] to have some since knocked into them about being a soldier.
S64.Q97.Full: Well I'm the kind of a guy that like this sort of life of moving around quite a bit and being outside all the time. There are a few things that the army does that are silly. For one they waste to much time getting things done. They don't get things organized like they should have. The food problem is very poorly run here. We stand in line for an hour or more to get a skimpy meal sometimes. There is mess halls close to us but we have to eat at the farthest one and that takes up half our time. They don't pay us regular as they should & they don't let us out of camp enough to let us enjoy a little freedom once in a while. The way things are run mow it seems we are like prisoners. We march to & from chow & to & from the toilets. In fact we march every place. The Non Coms [Noncommissioned officers] & C.O. [Commanding Officer] are plenty swell here but don't give us a chance to do anything we want to do. The fellows here ough [ought] to have some since knocked into them about being a soldier.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: I sure wish they would do away with a lot of infantile regulations in the Air Force Technical Schools. Also I wish some management could be made to efficiently take care of and feed the men at the mess halls.
S64.Q97.Full: I sure wish they would do away with a lot of infantile regulations in the Air Force Technical Schools. Also I wish some management could be made to efficiently take care of and feed the men at the mess halls.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q97.F: Chow has been getting pretty rigged out here. The meat & vegetables which are bought are usually the best but the food is usually spoiled in the way its prepared. There are about 6 mess halls on the camp. 5 of them are over crowded about nine tenths of the time, while the other mess hall is closed & not in use.
S64.Q97.Full: Chow has been getting pretty rigged out here. The meat & vegetables which are bought are usually the best but the food is usually spoiled in the way its prepared. There are about 6 mess halls on the camp. 5 of them are over crowded about nine tenths of the time, while the other mess hall is closed & not in use.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q96.M_marginalia: salary frozen versus high prices
S64.Q97.F: I wish to plead with you on the matter of peace. We'll win this war But for Christs sake lets not lose the peace. My chances of coming back are 50/50 But if I can die and know my ignominious death would help the world then I'm [unclear] nyu [/unclear] . Gut if we fuss around and fiddle faddle not take a definite stand we are lost as is the rest of the world. [/paragraph] In our Society we always take the
S64.Q97.C_1: [unclear] When [/unclear] both internally and externally that competitions or survival of the fittest is the only creed. this sprug from the type of animalistic, we thought behavior. But cooperation is basic whether in man or animal. [paragraph] Wilson went far during the last war not far enough. Lets take up where he left off.
S64.Q97.Full: I wish to plead with you on the matter of peace. We'll win this war But for Christs sake lets not lose the peace. My chances of coming back are 50/50 But if I can die and know my ignominious death would help the world then I'm [unclear] nyu [/unclear] . Gut if we fuss around and fiddle faddle not take a definite stand we are lost as is the rest of the world. [/paragraph] In our Society we always take the [unclear] When [/unclear] both internally and externally that competitions or survival of the fittest is the only creed. this sprug from the type of animalistic, we thought behavior. But cooperation is basic whether in man or animal. [paragraph] Wilson went far during the last war not far enough. Lets take up where he left off.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: Need better cooks at this camp they have good food to cook but they make a hell of a mess cooking it. (paragraph) I feel that lots of time is wasted in school. If they would take advantage of the time they would not have to get up in the middle of the night to start. 6 hours a day should be plenty.
S64.Q97.Full: Need better cooks at this camp they have good food to cook but they make a hell of a mess cooking it. (paragraph) I feel that lots of time is wasted in school. If they would take advantage of the time they would not have to get up in the middle of the night to start. 6 hours a day should be plenty.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: I was once an aviation cadet and was very proud to be one, but at primary flying school, 73% of my class was eliminated. This does not seem right, I am sure it was not the fault of all the cadets that were eliminated. Promises which were made to me when I enlisted were not kept when I was eliminated. [paragraph] There is to much waste of time
S64.Q97.C_1: and too many poor instructors in the technical training schools of the Air Corps.
S64.Q97.Full: I was once an aviation cadet and was very proud to be one, but at primary flying school, 73% of my class was eliminated. This does not seem right, I am sure it was not the fault of all the cadets that were eliminated. Promises which were made to me when I enlisted were not kept when I was eliminated. [paragraph] There is to much waste of time and too many poor instructors in the technical training schools of the Air Corps.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q97.F: In regard to this (Lowry Field No 2) camp, 1. The mess system is quite bad. An entire shift is forced to eat in one mess hall. This takes too long. As the school is dismissed at 11:30 and there is another roll call at 12:45. Some times some of the personell is late. 2. The Post Exchange is run sloppy and without regard to convenience to different hours that must be kept. The soft drink
S64.Q97.C_1: stand is constantly giving excuses to close. The same may be given about the Service Club Cafeteria. This field could be run as efficiently as Buckley Field if there was more interest taken into it. The Technical Training School is run like a Boy Scout Camp. Boy Scouts would be treated mor like men. Soldiers are supposed to be adults not children. It is my opinion that the Post Theatre could open at 1:30 and run continuously untill [until] 8:30. [paragraph] There should be more of an effort to permit the enlisted men (studied by his superiors for qualifications) to enter O.C.S. [Officer Candidate School] . Not by pull or power but by actual demonstration.
S64.Q97.Full: In regard to this (Lowry Field No 2) camp, 1. The mess system is quite bad. An entire shift is forced to eat in one mess hall. This takes too long. As the school is dismissed at 11:30 and there is another roll call at 12:45. Some times some of the personell is late. 2. The Post Exchange is run sloppy and without regard to convenience to different hours that must be kept. The soft drink stand is constantly giving excuses to close. The same may be given about the Service Club Cafeteria. This field could be run as efficiently as Buckley Field if there was more interest taken into it. The Technical Training School is run like a Boy Scout Camp. Boy Scouts would be treated mor like men. Soldiers are supposed to be adults not children. It is my opinion that the Post Theatre could open at 1:30 and run continuously untill [until] 8:30. [paragraph] There should be more of an effort to permit the enlisted men (studied by his superiors for qualifications) to enter O.C.S. [Officer Candidate School] . Not by pull or power but by actual demonstration.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: I think a soldier should be eligible for furlough every 4 mos. no matter what the conditions are either a student or in a tactical outfit. The cooks should be taught how to prepare the food the way a soldier likes it. They ruin a good meal by not preparing it right.
S64.Q97.Full: I think a soldier should be eligible for furlough every 4 mos. no matter what the conditions are either a student or in a tactical outfit. The cooks should be taught how to prepare the food the way a soldier likes it. They ruin a good meal by not preparing it right.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: In the army there is: (1) Too much excess paperwork, (2) not enough making use of man's capabilities, (3) Too much petty attention to trivialities, (4) Too much attention to set rules - sometimes exceptions should be made. (5) The absurdity and short sightedness of making men who work irregular hours, such as cooks, M.P.'s etc stand formation in off duty hours. (6)
S64.Q97.Full: In the army there is: (1) Too much excess paperwork, (2) not enough making use of man's capabilities, (3) Too much petty attention to trivialities, (4) Too much attention to set rules - sometimes exceptions should be made. (5) The absurdity and short sightedness of making men who work irregular hours, such as cooks, M.P.'s etc stand formation in off duty hours. (6)

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: In thes Air Force Tech. Schools why dont they pull the Ray we spend about 2 hours of study & practical work out of 7 The rest is dusting sweeping mopping & policeing. Very little discipline too much Red tape etc. Lets pull the cab & get this job done.
S64.Q97.Full: In thes Air Force Tech. Schools why dont they pull the Ray we spend about 2 hours of study & practical work out of 7 The rest is dusting sweeping mopping & policeing. Very little discipline too much Red tape etc. Lets pull the cab & get this job done.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: They should give a furlough at lease (least) one (underlined) a year in the Air Corp. If not why punish a man for going A.W.O.L. (absent without leave). They spend all their school time G I the school building & window. Let the 4F's and limited servicemen do this instead of letting them be non com & commissioned officers in Camp like Lowry Field #2 Denver Colorado.
S64.Q97.Full: They should give a furlough at lease (least) one (underlined) a year in the Air Corp. If not why punish a man for going A.W.O.L. (absent without leave). They spend all their school time G I the school building & window. Let the 4F's and limited servicemen do this instead of letting them be non com & commissioned officers in Camp like Lowry Field #2 Denver Colorado.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of furloughs but not passes
S64.Q95.M_marginalia: I haven't been long enough for a furlough, but I sure would like one.
S64.Q97.F: The chow could be better in some mess halls I cant understand why they dont serve the same quality of food at every mess hall and at every camp
S64.Q97.Full: The chow could be better in some mess halls I cant understand why they dont serve the same quality of food at every mess hall and at every camp

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: As a whole I am very well satisfied with my present army life.
S64.Q97.Full: As a whole I am very well satisfied with my present army life.

S64.Q97.C_1: ([unclear] course [/unclear] ) and the respect of a ([underline] any [/underline] ) soldier. Non-coms should also be picked for their ability to do their respective jobs.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q97.F: I have only been on this field a short time. My acquaintance with the non coms and officers are limited.
S64.Q97.Full: I have only been on this field a short time. My acquaintance with the non coms and officers are limited.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q97.F: I'm getting a good deal in the Army and have lots of ambition to get up in rank. My most serious gripe is that OCS[Officer Candidate School] is practically closed now and many of us are young, on our toes, & good officer candidate material. Many before us had much more opportunities for commissions because there were more opening. But I guess nothing can be done. -- Most of us are practically forced to buy War Bonds which is a minor point, but rather undemocratic of the Army.
S64.Q97.C_1: Also, as far as the army way of doing things --- most of us rebel now & then, not at what we must do, but because we are threatened with "Do this or else". We are too damn red-blooded to be bullied and this opinion doesn't represent the attitude of "weak sisters" either. Several non-coms in the Air Corps seem rather incompetent & possible there are too many ratings floating around. A PFC in the Infantry means for more than one in the Air Corps. The Army emphasizes petty rules (chicken-shit) quite often - Miami Beach & Col Kimberly are good examples of this ---Lowry isn't quite so bad. Also, the training (tech) which we received isn't tough or hard to understand. Why must non-coms & even officers treat us as though we were dumb animals & herd us around like cattle. An army man should be given more of a chance to stand on his own feet - make his own decisions. A married man in the army gets a good deal. Food is good - I'm find we're winning the war - Hell! Why skwawk??
S64.Q97.Full: I'm getting a good deal in the Army and have lots of ambition to get up in rank. My most serious gripe is that OCS[Officer Candidate School] is practically closed now and many of us are young, on our toes, & good officer candidate material. Many before us had much more opportunities for commissions because there were more opening. But I guess nothing can be done. -- Most of us are practically forced to buy War Bonds which is a minor point, but rather undemocratic of the Army.  Also, as far as the army way of doing things --- most of us rebel now & then, not at what we must do, but because we are threatened with "Do this or else". We are too damn red-blooded to be bullied and this opinion doesn't represent the attitude of "weak sisters" either. Several non-coms in the Air Corps seem rather incompetent & possible there are too many ratings floating around. A PFC in the Infantry means for more than one in the Air Corps. The Army emphasizes petty rules (chicken-shit) quite often - Miami Beach & Col Kimberly are good examples of this ---Lowry isn't quite so bad. Also, the training (tech) which we received isn't tough or hard to understand. Why must non-coms & even officers treat us as though we were dumb animals & herd us around like cattle. An army man should be given more of a chance to stand on his own feet - make his own decisions. A married man in the army gets a good deal. Food is good - I'm find we're winning the war - Hell! Why skwawk??

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q96.M_marginalia: Added on to the Answer 1: for some & much worse for others.
S64.Q97.F: In most of the camp's have been in the chow system has been poorly run. [paragraph] I am going to a tech school now. It is very poorly run. All you have to do to pass is be on time every day and have on clean clothes & look neat.
S64.Q97.C_1: I think the army has more men than they need. I believe they are wasteing money in some tech schools. [paragraph] If I had it to do all over again I would get drafted just like I did this time.
S64.Q97.Full: In most of the camp's have been in the chow system has been poorly run. [paragraph] I am going to a tech school now. It is very poorly run. All you have to do to pass is be on time every day and have on clean clothes & look neat. I think the army has more men than they need. I believe they are wasteing money in some tech schools. [paragraph] If I had it to do all over again I would get drafted just like I did this time.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: I don't believe soldiers are given the job they are best qualified for. I know I was forced into my job against my will. I know I could be a much better use to the army in the type of work I done (did) in civilian life. As it is I figure I will be of little use to the army.
S64.Q97.Full: I don't believe soldiers are given the job they are best qualified for. I know I was forced into my job against my will. I know I could be a much better use to the army in the type of work I done (did) in civilian life. As it is I figure I will be of little use to the army.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: Some of the big mistakes of the army are it does not segregate its men as to previous service, training or positions they once held or received. There are too many mistakes and too much time lost in elementary training of men who have had a year or two previous service. There are also too many overnight first [unclear] ther [/unclear] graders with little previous service, wired in the technical schools and permanent party jobs, who should be in actual combat. Why let the buck privates do all the fighting.
S64.Q97.Full: Some of the big mistakes of the army are it does not segregate its men as to previous service, training or positions they once held or received. There are too many mistakes and too much time lost in elementary training of men who have had a year or two previous service. There are also too many overnight first [unclear] ther [/unclear] graders with little previous service, wired in the technical schools and permanent party jobs, who should be in actual combat. Why let the buck privates do all the fighting.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q97.F: In general the army is very much organized, lots better than, the world war 1, and it is still being improved upon, from an enlisted mans viewpoint. [paragraph] being in a T.T.C.S. [Tactical Terminal Control Systems] we usually dont get a lot of actual training in weapons but that is being improved.
S64.Q97.Full: In general the army is very much organized, lots better than, the world war 1, and it is still being improved upon, from an enlisted mans viewpoint. [paragraph] being in a T.T.C.S. [Tactical Terminal Control Systems] we usually dont get a lot of actual training in weapons but that is being improved.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: In My Opinion: The system of schooling in the AAFTTC is lousy. There isn't any set system for teaching the subjects. The teachers or instructors as they are called aren't in the least bit worried or really informed as to what their students actually know. I go to school for 7 hrs, actually do about 2 hours of real work and goof off the rest of the time and I like school. The instructors have subjects which can be made interesting but it seems as though the method of choosing instructors ["Three volunteers" you, you and you"] , not even a question as
S64.Q97.C_1: to whether they want the job or are capable of doing it. Starting school at 4:45 AM, one hour earlier means nothing more than spreading the work over another hour and making a student even more disgusted. The instructor should be in charge of the class, not some building supervisor or person who out ranks the instructor and interrupts because he thinks he can kill some time in class and give the students some knowledge that is 3/4 talk. This usually happens when the class is going along OK and the students are getting a vague idea of whats going on. _ One group of men whom I knew of very well were called the "Victory Squad", they were stationed at Miami Beach when I was there. [deletion] They were [/deletion] Their group was composed of men who were in no way fit for military service but we're being kept because some hotels needed janitors and gardners or just plain detail men. They were earning $50 per month. If at home, they would have their friends, families and some might have jobs which might be of some value to the war. My friend who was in this example of Army efficiency, was a chemical engineer, Grad M.I.T., Trouble shooter at the T.N.T. plant at Kankakee, Ill. {Area 16,000 Acres cost $12,000,000} His rank was Drill Instructor. He WAS in a very essential job but had a much more essential job training men, who were of no use as soldiers, for combat.
S64.Q97.Full: In My Opinion: The system of schooling in the AAFTTC is lousy. There isn't any set system for teaching the subjects. The teachers or instructors as they are called aren't in the least bit worried or really informed as to what their students actually know. I go to school for 7 hrs, actually do about 2 hours of real work and goof off the rest of the time and I like school. The instructors have subjects which can be made interesting but it seems as though the method of choosing instructors ["Three volunteers" you, you and you"] , not even a question as to whether they want the job or are capable of doing it. Starting school at 4:45 AM, one hour earlier means nothing more than spreading the work over another hour and making a student even more disgusted. The instructor should be in charge of the class, not some building supervisor or person who out ranks the instructor and interrupts because he thinks he can kill some time in class and give the students some knowledge that is 3/4 talk. This usually happens when the class is going along OK and the students are getting a vague idea of whats going on. _ One group of men whom I knew of very well were called the "Victory Squad", they were stationed at Miami Beach when I was there. [deletion] They were [/deletion] Their group was composed of men who were in no way fit for military service but we're being kept because some hotels needed janitors and gardners or just plain detail men. They were earning $50 per month. If at home, they would have their friends, families and some might have jobs which might be of some value to the war. My friend who was in this example of Army efficiency, was a chemical engineer, Grad M.I.T., Trouble shooter at the T.N.T. plant at Kankakee, Ill. {Area 16,000 Acres cost $12,000,000} His rank was Drill Instructor. He WAS in a very essential job but had a much more essential job training men, who were of no use as soldiers, for combat.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: If a man was granted a furlough once every 3 or 4 months there wouldn't be so many men going AWOL. Put leaders in, who understand their men and conditions about them not some old Grouch. All in all the Army is operated fairly square.
S64.Q97.Full: If a man was granted a furlough once every 3 or 4 months there wouldn't be so many men going AWOL. Put leaders in, who understand their men and conditions about them not some old Grouch. All in all the Army is operated fairly square.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: I think the reasons for things should be explained, many of the men would be more willing if they knew why and what for. {paragraph} Our non com's should be tough to lead the men, not boss them. {paragraph} Theres too much swearing in the army. {paragraph} I'm a young lad of 18, a son of a soldier, I'm glad to fight for my country but for petes [deletion] sk [/deletion] sake, don't send the married men into combat. {paragraph} Lets not make the mistake
S64.Q97.C_1: we made last time by not entering World affairs like President Wilson suggested. Lets strive for a United States of the World. With an equal chance for all. That's what I'm fighting for, [underlined] fair play [/underlined] .
S64.Q97.Full: I think the reasons for things should be explained, many of the men would be more willing if they knew why and what for. {paragraph} Our non com's should be tough to lead the men, not boss them. {paragraph} Theres too much swearing in the army. {paragraph} I'm a young lad of 18, a son of a soldier, I'm glad to fight for my country but for petes [deletion] sk [/deletion] sake, don't send the married men into combat. {paragraph} Lets not make the mistake we made last time by not entering World affairs like President Wilson suggested. Lets strive for a United States of the World. With an equal chance for all. That's what I'm fighting for, [underlined] fair play [/underlined] .

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q97.F: The army wants their men to look neat and I think they should take more pains to fit their men properly because I have seen men [unclear] go [/unclear] down the street in lose fitting clothes and it sure looks sloppy. [paragraph] It, the army I mean, should see to it that the men have all their clothes. I have a case which I know must have come up many times. When
S64.Q97.C_1: I was shipped from Florida. I had my fatigues in the cleaners so I had to on leave without them. Since that time the cleaning bill being paid for by myself, the army had gotten the clothes back but has made me attempt to return them to me. I need them badly because I only have one pair. I went to supply sargent to get another pair and I want to know why I should have to pay for something I didn't lose. Another thing I left postage with that training group to send them to me and someone just pocketed the money.
S64.Q97.Full: The army wants their men to look neat and I think they should take more pains to fit their men properly because I have seen men [unclear] go [/unclear] down the street in lose fitting clothes and it sure looks sloppy. [paragraph] It, the army I mean, should see to it that the men have all their clothes. I have a case which I know must have come up many times. When  I was shipped from Florida. I had my fatigues in the cleaners so I had to on leave without them. Since that time the cleaning bill being paid for by myself, the army had gotten the clothes back but has made me attempt to return them to me. I need them badly because I only have one pair. I went to supply sargent to get another pair and I want to know why I should have to pay for something I didn't lose. Another thing I left postage with that training group to send them to me and someone just pocketed the money.

S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: Remarking about fourlough. well 11 months in the service and have had no furlough while other fellows 2 & 3 and 4 month in the service have been getting passes and furlough. it is not fair to one and not all and should consider a soldier who has not been home in a eleven months should get more than a 10 day furlough.
S64.Q97.Full: Remarking about fourlough. well 11 months in the service and have had no furlough while other fellows 2 & 3 and 4 month in the service have been getting passes and furlough. it is not fair to one and not all and should consider a soldier who has not been home in a eleven months should get more than a 10 day furlough.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: This matter of promotions gets under my skin. I am an airplane mechanic working on the line. Responsible for a plane and the lives of men who fly yet men who are in the supply and orderly room, men too irresponsible and generally useless are made cpl. and sgt. Same thing on every field, men who are not fit to hold a responsible job are shoved into P. P. positions.
S64.Q97.C_1: and given ratings, while really good men on real jobs sweat out years sometimes without any recognition.
S64.Q97.Full: This matter of promotions gets under my skin. I am an airplane mechanic working on the line. Responsible for a plane and the lives of men who fly yet men who are in the supply and orderly room, men too irresponsible and generally useless are made cpl. and sgt. Same thing on every field, men who are not fit to hold a responsible job are shoved into P. P. positions. and given ratings, while really good men on real jobs sweat out years sometimes without any recognition.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: The Technical Training Command could be run a lot better. By this I mean when one Instructor tell you one thing and another tells you something else, you don't know what to answer when a test is given you. [paragraph] The Boys are not getting enough time to study to be the mechanics they should
S64.Q97.C_1: be. They are learning more command tactics then mechanic and to be responsible for an airplane you must know what you are doing. To do this successfully you must have some time for study. Passes could be given out more than once a week in some situations also. The morale is very low at Sheppard Field. There is nothing to prevent this and the officers (some of them) just make it worse by restricting and giving men detail work that do not mean nothing except a ([underline] nice [/underline] ) talking to.
S64.Q97.Full: The Technical Training Command could be run a lot better. By this I mean when one Instructor tell you one thing and another tells you something else, you don't know what to answer when a test is given you. [paragraph] The Boys are not getting enough time to study to be the mechanics they should  be. They are learning more command tactics then mechanic and to be responsible for an airplane you must know what you are doing. To do this successfully you must have some time for study. Passes could be given out more than once a week in some situations also. The morale is very low at Sheppard Field. There is nothing to prevent this and the officers (some of them) just make it worse by restricting and giving men detail work that do not mean nothing except a ([underline] nice [/underline] ) talking to.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page, A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: Well the only complaint I have about army life is that our camp here is over crowded. When ever a fellow gets a day off he usually wants to go to town. Down here it is usually impossible to go because we don't have the adequate transportation to handle the Saturday rush. [paragraph] Not having a furlough in the 9 month I spent in the army generally would make a soldier gripe. I think each
S64.Q97.C_1: soldiers should be given a furlough after serving that much time in the service.
S64.Q97.C_2: I feel that the single men in our squadron should have just as much right to be allowed to go in town while not on duty. The married men with wives living in town are the only ones entitled to class A pass while as the other hand some of us single fellows have earned class A basses by good grades in school but the squadron will not issue passes to us. It seems a married man has more privileges.
S64.Q97.Full: Well the only complaint I have about army life is that our camp here is over crowded. When ever a fellow gets a day off he usually wants to go to town. Down here it is usually impossible to go because we don't have the adequate transportation to handle the Saturday rush. [paragraph] Not having a furlough in the 9 month I spent in the army generally would make a soldier gripe. I think each  soldiers should be given a furlough after serving that much time in the service. I feel that the single men in our squadron should have just as much right to be allowed to go in town while not on duty. The married men with wives living in town are the only ones entitled to class A pass while as the other hand some of us single fellows have earned class A basses by good grades in school but the squadron will not issue passes to us. It seems a married man has more privileges.

S64.Q97.F: I think that a soldier should automatically get a furlough upon serving 6 mo. [months] of if attending tech schools or any other army specialist schools immediately upon finishing. Food situation here is terrible investigations should be made in all camps. Sports should be stressed more as physical exercise.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: I think the camp I am in now does not help a soldier in having a little fun. What they should have is about 5 to 10 dance halls and lots of fresh drinks, even a glass of beer would help a soldier in having a little fun. The town is a place for a soldier to stay out of. First of all they rob you by charging you double for [unclear] sadar [/unclear] meals & etc. I know for a fact if a soldier goes in town just a couple of times,
S64.Q97.C_1: and has a little fun, it cost him to much money. So they should have more dance halls with girls from various [insertion] high or college [/insertion] schools. Not just any girl, because in town the girls there are not likely [unclear] diseased [/unclear] , but some of them are. It is not likely the soldier to look for a sex relationship, but it is mostly the girls fault. I think that 95% of our soldiers are clean and well educated gentlemen, and don't go out for these sex relationships. So I don't see why the army don't give the fellow in this camp & other camps all over the United States a little pleasure after their weeks work.
S64.Q97.Full: I think the camp I am in now does not help a soldier in having a little fun. What they should have is about 5 to 10 dance halls and lots of fresh drinks, even a glass of beer would help a soldier in having a little fun. The town is a place for a soldier to stay out of. First of all they rob you by charging you double for [unclear] sadar [/unclear] meals & etc. I know for a fact if a soldier goes in town just a couple of times, and has a little fun, it cost him to much money. So they should have more dance halls with girls from various [insertion] high or college [/insertion] schools. Not just any girl, because in town the girls there are not likely [unclear] diseased [/unclear] , but some of them are. It is not likely the soldier to look for a sex relationship, but it is mostly the girls fault. I think that 95% of our soldiers are clean and well educated gentlemen, and don't go out for these sex relationships. So I don't see why the army don't give the fellow in this camp & other camps all over the United States a little pleasure after their weeks work.

S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: Would like to know why a soldier, who is physicaly & mentally qualified Can't get over and see some action. Tried every possible way to get over and am still going to one school after another.
S64.Q97.Full: Would like to know why a soldier, who is physicaly & mentally qualified Can't get over and see some action. Tried every possible way to get over and am still going to one school after another.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: I am not quite 20 yet, but in the 10 months I've been in the Army Air Corps, I've seen and heard a lot of things that were new and strange to me. But as a whole, the Army has made a man of me. It has made me more self-reliant than I would ever have had to be back home. But, here in Texas there's only one thing that makes me feel like
S64.Q97.C_1: disowning the Army, and that is the 2 hours daily Physical Training, with the sun as bright at a 300 watt bulb, and the temperature hits about 116[degree sign] in the shade (NO EXAGGERATION) - and no relief in sight. Then is when a soldier's morale is at its lowest. It makes him wonder if the Army Officials have any brains at all. Because too much sun [underline] could [/underline] kill a man. [paragraph] I'm setting here now, writing this and the sweat is running off of me in buckets fulls. And no relief in sight. And its been this way for the last 6 weeks. Being from the North I guess I cant take it so well. [paragraph] So, if you could do [underline] any [/underline] [underline] thing [/underline] at all about this problem, I, and all the soldiers on this field, would really appreciate it.
S64.Q97.Full: I am not quite 20 yet, but in the 10 months I've been in the Army Air Corps, I've seen and heard a lot of things that were new and strange to me. But as a whole, the Army has made a man of me. It has made me more self-reliant than I would ever have had to be back home. But, here in Texas there's only one thing that makes me feel like disowning the Army, and that is the 2 hours daily Physical Training, with the sun as bright at a 300 watt bulb, and the temperature hits about 116[degree sign] in the shade (NO EXAGGERATION) - and no relief in sight. Then is when a soldier's morale is at its lowest. It makes him wonder if the Army Officials have any brains at all. Because too much sun [underline] could [/underline] kill a man. [paragraph] I'm setting here now, writing this and the sweat is running off of me in buckets fulls. And no relief in sight. And its been this way for the last 6 weeks. Being from the North I guess I cant take it so well. [paragraph] So, if you could do [underline] any [/underline] [underline] thing [/underline] at all about this problem, I, and all the soldiers on this field, would really appreciate it.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: I am from N.Y. where the heat is hardly over 75 degrees in our hottest days. We are sent to Texas where the heat in the summer hits one 115 degrees sometimes. We are not used to it. Can't take it so hot. They give us two hours of tortuous drill on a hot field. Many men faint or get sick. We stagger home after P.T. and I'm not kidding. Don't forget we go to school 7 hrs. a day for 6 days per week. In school you stand don't sit. You come back
S64.Q97.C_1: from school just in time for P.T. [Physical Training] I've lost 30 lbs [pounds] more since I'm here (3 months). Something has to be done about P.T. (Physical Training). This is the first time I've ever been in a place so hot. I'm losing my morale because of that and also because none of us expects a furlough. The Air Corps it seems don't believe in giving furloughs and other branches do. They should have it that a man gets a furlough after school, at least let him see his loved ones once before he goes over. Give him that break.
S64.Q97.Full: I am from N.Y. where the heat is hardly over 75 degrees in our hottest days. We are sent to Texas where the heat in the summer hits one 115 degrees sometimes. We are not used to it. Can't take it so hot. They give us two hours of tortuous drill on a hot field. Many men faint or get sick. We stagger home after P.T. and I'm not kidding. Don't forget we go to school 7 hrs. a day for 6 days per week. In school you stand don't sit. You come back from school just in time for P.T. [Physical Training] I've lost 30 lbs [pounds] more since I'm here (3 months). Something has to be done about P.T. (Physical Training). This is the first time I've ever been in a place so hot. I'm losing my morale because of that and also because none of us expects a furlough. The Air Corps it seems don't believe in giving furloughs and other branches do. They should have it that a man gets a furlough after school, at least let him see his loved ones once before he goes over. Give him that break.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: In general I think they would get more out of the fellows at Sheppard Field, Texas if they didn't have to spend so much time on the field, there is no time to study any mechanics outside of school and it is too hot on the field and when we return each day we are so tired out we sometimes go right to bed and don't even write a letter home and let our family know how we are. That is one thing that
S64.Q97.C_1: causes the soldiers to dislike it so very much at this field & many others that I have heard about.
S64.Q97.Full: In general I think they would get more out of the fellows at Sheppard Field, Texas if they didn't have to spend so much time on the field, there is no time to study any mechanics outside of school and it is too hot on the field and when we return each day we are so tired out we sometimes go right to bed and don't even write a letter home and let our family know how we are. That is one thing that  causes the soldiers to dislike it so very much at this field & many others that I have heard about.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: All I can add is that I am glad to be able to get this training now to help win the war and to help me after the war because I don't think it could be bought by me.
S64.Q97.Full: All I can add is that I am glad to be able to get this training now to help win the war and to help me after the war because I don't think it could be bought by me.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: I think a soldier should be given a chance to see his parents or family more often as it does him a great deal better & he is not disgusted with army life as much. Many soldiers are taken to camps so far from home that it would be impossible to see his parents or family with a week furlough.
S64.Q97.Full: I think a soldier should be given a chance to see his parents or family more often as it does him a great deal better & he is not disgusted with army life as much. Many soldiers are taken to camps so far from home that it would be impossible to see his parents or family with a week furlough.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: Throw about 1/2 of the desk jobs and red tape out of Wash. D.C. & try to pound it into the officers head that we men in the armed forces are not dogs & we only ask that we be treated like soldiers. When a man has to be threatened every time he is told to do something, it makes it rather hard to carry out these orders.
S64.Q97.Full: Throw about 1/2 of the desk jobs and red tape out of Wash. D.C. & try to pound it into the officers head that we men in the armed forces are not dogs & we only ask that we be treated like soldiers. When a man has to be threatened every time he is told to do something, it makes it rather hard to carry out these orders.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)

S64.Q97.F: Better food is rather better cooks + better living condition
S64.Q97.Full: Better food is rather better cooks + better living condition

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: Before coming to Sheppard Field I had been told on several occasions that this field was the worse [worst] place in the world to take the Air Corps Basic Training, and after spending over 50 days here I find that is quite true. [paragraph] Here it is the month of August
S64.Q97.C_1: which is the hottest month in the year in Texas, and yet our new training schedule calls for 2.1/2 hours [underline] more [/underline] ) marching etc in the evening than before. I have lost over 15 lbs of weight since I arrived at Sheppard when I need to gain 25 oz. 30 lbs to weight that I should. [paragraph] Boys from the northern states when they arrive at Sheppard Field immediately develope a strong hatred for the State of Texas which isn't fair to the people of Texas, or the state itself. [paragraph] I think they should teach us more about airplanes etc instead of so much close order drilling every day. It is no wonder that this field gives a fellow such a low morale standing. Anway I have high hopes that the next place will be at least some better than Sheppard Field.
S64.Q97.Full: Before coming to Sheppard Field I had been told on several occasions that this field was the worse [worst] place in the world to take the Air Corps Basic Training, and after spending over 50 days here I find that is quite true. [paragraph] Here it is the month of August which is the hottest month in the year in Texas, and yet our new training schedule calls for 2.1/2 hours [underline] more [/underline] ) marching etc in the evening than before. I have lost over 15 lbs of weight since I arrived at Sheppard when I need to gain 25 oz. 30 lbs to weight that I should. [paragraph] Boys from the northern states when they arrive at Sheppard Field immediately develope a strong hatred for the State of Texas which isn't fair to the people of Texas, or the state itself. [paragraph] I think they should teach us more about airplanes etc instead of so much close order drilling every day. It is no wonder that this field gives a fellow such a low morale standing. Anway I have high hopes that the next place will be at least some better than Sheppard Field.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Other/No answer
S64.Q95.M_marginalia: I have only been in the Army 3 mos (months).
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: I don't think enlisted men should come to attention when an officer walks in a room. (paragraph) In this field something should be done about flys. (flies). (paragraph) Soldiers should should be allowed to go around twice at the mes shall if they feel they can eat [deletion] [/deletion] all they get.
S64.Q97.C_1: At this field where it is so dry and hot, soldiers taking basic training should be allowed to carry their canteens with them at all times while on the drill field or physical training field. [paragraph] Laundry service should be speeded up a little. [paragraph] There should be more Post Exchanges at this field, because when a soldier is of duty and wants to get something he usually has to wait in line for anything sometimes even to get in the P.X. Then another line to each counter. [paragraph] Barracks are crowded and they are slow, very slow in shipping men to their proper outfits from this basic training center.
S64.Q97.Full: I don't think enlisted men should come to attention when an officer walks in a room. (paragraph) In this field something should be done about flys. (flies). (paragraph) Soldiers should should be allowed to go around twice at the mes shall if they feel they can eat [deletion] [/deletion] all they get. At this field where it is so dry and hot, soldiers taking basic training should be allowed to carry their canteens with them at all times while on the drill field or physical training field. [paragraph] Laundry service should be speeded up a little. [paragraph] There should be more Post Exchanges at this field, because when a soldier is of duty and wants to get something he usually has to wait in line for anything sometimes even to get in the P.X. Then another line to each counter. [paragraph] Barracks are crowded and they are slow, very slow in shipping men to their proper outfits from this basic training center.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: The army is swell, from what I have heard. I have been stationed at Sheppard Field there for two months, and I had rather die and go to hell than have to spend another two months here; that is my opinion and also eighty thousand other men who are stationed here. We have close order drill for six hours and their P.T. until 1730
S64.Q97.C_1: If that will help win the war, the Germans & Japanese must be getting mighty week [weak] .
S64.Q97.Full: The army is swell, from what I have heard. I have been stationed at Sheppard Field there for two months, and I had rather die and go to hell than have to spend another two months here; that is my opinion and also eighty thousand other men who are stationed here. We have close order drill for six hours and their P.T. until 1730 If that will help win the war, the Germans & Japanese must be getting mighty week [weak] .
