[paragraph] I realize that governmental inefficiency, red tape, + waste has always been great, + is becoming increasingly so, [underline] by leaps + bounds [/underline] . Apparently noone knows what to do about that (except possibly to Vote in the Republicans -- compare the records ! However its obvious that there is a stupendous amount of manpower [underline] mal [/underline] -- distribution [distributed] , with a large part coming into the army That would seem to me to make it possible to eliminate or at least alleviate the one petty grievance I have pertaining to my "work" in the Army. That is, the 12 hour stift [shift] . It should because it easily could, be reduced to 8 hours, which has been shown to be a more efficient way of expending labor Conditions outside give every indication that 3 shifts of 8 hours each are more productive, more fruitful, than 2 stretches of 12 hours each. So, why doesn't the army wise up -- we're doing as important a job as the private firm, now, and should do it in as an efficient a way as is possible. [paragraph] If you've read this far, please realize that I've purposely given wholly ( insofar as is humanly possible) unbiased answers slightly on the pessimistic side. And allow therefore,

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q97.F: I realize that the best men available, that is to a certain degree, are now and were classifying men into their respective Branches of service and to their respective duties but there still is to much of ill placed men going on. When classifying a man you should take into consideration both aptitude and the liking that a man has for a thing. The latter being the most important. Being pleased with the
S64.Q97.C_1: job is 75% of the job. You want a man and his mind working together not a machine like robot. Also please don't put a man in a job just because 200 men are needed and he makes the 200th.
S64.Q97.Full: I realize that the best men available, that is to a certain degree, are now and were classifying men into their respective Branches of service and to their respective duties but there still is to much of ill placed men going on. When classifying a man you should take into consideration both aptitude and the liking that a man has for a thing. The latter being the most important. Being pleased with the  job is 75% of the job. You want a man and his mind working together not a machine like robot. Also please don't put a man in a job just because 200 men are needed and he makes the 200th.

S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q97.F: In this group twelve hours is a working day. There is never a goal to be reached. Ships fly continuously & do require more maintenance. I think if more men were available this would be a much happier group. Men shipping out
S64.Q97.C_1: would be able to get a better line drawing & full [unclear] ???? [/unclear] in his job if he were allowed to stay here longer in some cases.

I think if more men were available this would be a much happier group. Men shipping out would be able to get a better line drawing & full [unclear] ???? [/unclear] in his job if he were allowed to stay here longer in some cases.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: I think a soldier in the air force, especially maintenance crews, should only work 8 hours a day. At the end of 8 hours a man quits working because he figures he has done his share for that day. If he is working 12 hours a day he only does 8 hours work anyhow. the rest of the time is spent fooling around. Each hangs
S64.Q97.C_1: should be furnished enough men so that they would only have to work 8 hours a day. The care on this field is that we have to many planes for the small amount of men we have to take care of them. When a man quits work at the end of 12 hour a day 7 days a week he is to tired to do anything but sleep. He doesn't have time to go out and have a good time and relax a little. I guess we all know the old adage "all work and no play Makes Jack a dull Boy." This seems to be the case at this particular field cause we don't have enough men for the amount of equipment we have. We are doing 24 hours a day work with the amount of men it is supposed to take to do 8 hours work.
S64.Q97.Full: I think a soldier in the air force, especially maintenance crews, should only work 8 hours a day. At the end of 8 hours a man quits working because he figures he has done his share for that day. If he is working 12 hours a day he only does 8 hours work anyhow. the rest of the time is spent fooling around. Each hangs should be furnished enough men so that they would only have to work 8 hours a day. The care on this field is that we have to many planes for the small amount of men we have to take care of them. When a man quits work at the end of 12 hour a day 7 days a week he is to tired to do anything but sleep. He doesn't have time to go out and have a good time and relax a little. I guess we all know the old adage "all work and no play Makes Jack a dull Boy." This seems to be the case at this particular field cause we don't have enough men for the amount of equipment we have. We are doing 24 hours a day work with the amount of men it is supposed to take to do 8 hours work.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q97.F: Concerning question 96: My father is in a non essential job in a large manufacturing town. His pay has not been increased in comparison with the "war workers", making living conditions much worse. We live in a rented house & due to the crowded conditions of the town it was sold out from under us at an outrageous price. There are no houses to rent & it will mean looking for a house to buy
S64.Q97.C_1: & the prices being asked today are terrible. Consequently we will have to pay for above the fair price for a house.
S64.Q97.Full: Concerning question 96: My father is in a non essential job in a large manufacturing town. His pay has not been increased in comparison with the "war workers", making living conditions much worse. We live in a rented house & due to the crowded conditions of the town it was sold out from under us at an outrageous price. There are no houses to rent & it will mean looking for a house to buy  & the prices being asked today are terrible. Consequently we will have to pay for above the fair price for a house.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q97.F: Dedicated to the present [underlined] suckers [/underlined] in Washington Three years before this present conflagration, war with Japan was very evident and even predicted in many magazine articles, but the people and their masses who seldom read fit reading material were blind to the fact that this war was as obvious as they see it today. The people and their masses are willing to admit their many mistakes today, but this doesn't do any good for our war effort - it just lowers our morale thinking how stupid we were. [underlined] So lets wake up while theres still time [/underlined]
S64.Q97.C_1: The Russians are the source of comment today in many leading magazine articles and I as a soldier along with huge numbers of others agree fully with these articles. These articles warn against Communism, but very few people are paying attention to them- their acting the same way about Russia as they acted about Japan. They don't care! They just want the present war over with and forget about war strategy. This present war involves the Conquest of the world by one nation- who knows we may have plans for world domination in our own secret little way, but Im an american I hope we do win this war, but I hope the right leaders are picked to give us a lasting peace- if they aren't I will be one to [unclear] revolutionize [/unclear] or revolt against a [unclear] hegemony [/unclear] form of government- [underline] momaties what kind of a job jus offered to remain quiet [/underline] Im going to remain a true american sticking to democratic principles. Its too bad propaganda doesnt work and take effect upon everybody that has to take it. Because this will be your big job after this war- trying to fool and bewilder the public [underline] and you shall, [/underline] but their will be a few to see through your schemes and these few will give you plenty of trouble Mr & Mrs Leaders of america tommorrow. Walter Winchill article

S64.Q97.F: What is the use of making any remarks nobody even reads these things anyway. And if someone did read them it's about time they stopped & go out & get themselves a job in an essential industry; or do something about winning this war instead of sitting around reading. They could save all this ink & paper & use it for a good purpose instead of [continued on next page] [/continued on next page]
S64.Q97.C_1: making out all these stupid interviews. It's about time congress did something about winning this war; I think it would be a good idea to drop a few egges [eggs] on this country, it might wake up some of those boneheads in Wash. We're fighting this war for one reason - to make the rich man richer!
S64.Q97.Full: What is the use of making any remarks nobody even reads these things anyway. And if someone did read them it's about time they stopped & go out & get themselves a job in an essential industry; or do something about winning this war instead of sitting around reading. document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: I think I could do more good on my father's farm then I can in the army. My father got sick [unclear] since [/unclear] I've gotten the army and is not able to do his work and he has a large farm an a lot of stock. I ask for a discharge but havent got any results yet and I am needed very bad. I also have a wife and baby that need my help very bad.
S64.Q97.Full: I think I could do more good on my father's farm then I can in the army. My father got sick [unclear] since [/unclear] I've gotten the army and is not able to do his work and he has a large farm an a lot of stock. I ask for a discharge but havent got any results yet and I am needed very bad. I also have a wife and baby that need my help very bad.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: I think the classification end of the army is lax in its placement of men. About 80% of the men I have met are doing jobs that they know little about. I myself holding a toolmaking papers expected upon entering the army to get in a mechanical division but after 4 or 5 classifications I now carry bombs back and forth which any man with
S64.Q97.C_1: a half a brain could do. Making 132 in the army intelligence test I applied for OCS [Officer Candidate School] . They would not release me from air corps ordinance therefore stifling me from getting ahead. Another thing is the breaking up of men. You make friends and every 2 months you are shipped with a different outfit. This makes one very discontent and discourages your working attitude. It breeds the "I don't give a damn feeling."
S64.Q97.Full: I think the classification end of the army is lax in its placement of men. About 80% of the men I have met are doing jobs that they know little about. I myself holding a toolmaking papers expected upon entering the army to get in a mechanical division but after 4 or 5 classifications I now carry bombs back and forth which any man with a half a brain could do. Making 132 in the army intelligence test I applied for OCS [Officer Candidate School] . They would not release me from air corps ordinance therefore stifling me from getting ahead. Another thing is the breaking up of men. You make friends and every 2 months you are shipped with a different outfit. This makes one very discontent and discourages your working attitude. It breeds the "I don't give a damn feeling."

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: One thing that really burns our squadron as a [underline] whole [/underline] is that our 1st Sgt is drawing flying pay when he is a grounded gunner and never flies for his flight pay, whenever we get grounded [underline] we [/underline] loose [underline] all [/underline] our stripes. [paragraph] He should have [underline] too [/underline] but he kept his rating. That is my disagreeable point in army life. It's all brown nosing. And I can't do it [underline] that [/underline] way for I don't believe in getting anywhere by illegal means.
S64.Q97.Full: One thing that really burns our squadron as a [underline] whole [/underline] is that our 1st Sgt is drawing flying pay when he is a grounded gunner and never flies for his flight pay, whenever we get grounded [underline] we [/underline] loose [underline] all [/underline] our stripes. [paragraph] He should have [underline] too [/underline] but he kept his rating. That is my disagreeable point in army life. It's all brown nosing. And I can't do it [underline] that [/underline] way for I don't believe in getting anywhere by illegal means.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: In our Air Force we are only allowed 14 days home a year. In other outfits they get their 30 days. A fellow should be given more chance to see his folks + wife more often. I think he will be able to fight better. [paragraph] I think there is too much
S64.Q97.C_1: wasting of foods
S64.Q97.Full: In our Air Force we are only allowed 14 days home a year. In other outfits they get their 30 days. A fellow should be given more chance to see his folks + wife more often. I think he will be able to fight better. [paragraph] I think there is too much wasting of foods

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: I think that when a soldier is sent to a technical school he should do the work he was taught. [insertion] I [/insertion] [insertion] was [/insertion] [deletion] am [/deletion] in the Air Corps at Miami beach and shipped to Lansing Mich. to Aircraft Armorer's school. There, I learned to take apart, fix and assemble the 20 MM cannon, 37 MM and the .50 and .30 caliber machine guns.
S64.Q97.C_1: From Lansing, I was sent to Salt Lake City and was put in the 2nd Air Force which is heavy bombardment B-17 + B-24's. There planes don't even carry the 20 MM. or 37 MM. At Salt Lake they railroaded me into the Air Force ordnance, and I now am at another base, filling sand practice bombs. [paragraph] I think that when the Army trains a man to do one particular job, he should be put in that job. Here I am, trained as an armorer and told now, to forget it all. This seems to me like a huge waste of money and time. I think if the public knew how their War Bond money was wasted, they would cease to buy another cent worth.
S64.Q97.Full: I think that when a soldier is sent to a technical school he should do the work he was taught. [insertion] I [/insertion] [insertion] was [/insertion] [deletion] am [/deletion] in the Air Corps at Miami beach and shipped to Lansing Mich. to Aircraft Armorer's school. There, I learned to take apart, fix and assemble the 20 MM cannon, 37 MM and the .50 and .30 caliber machine guns.  From Lansing, I was sent to Salt Lake City and was put in the 2nd Air Force which is heavy bombardment B-17 + B-24's. There planes don't even carry the 20 MM. or 37 MM. At Salt Lake they railroaded me into the Air Force ordnance, and I now am at another base, filling sand practice bombs. [paragraph] I think that when the Army trains a man to do one particular job, he should be put in that job. Here I am, trained as an armorer and told now, to forget it all. This seems to me like a huge waste of money and time. I think if the public knew how their War Bond money was wasted, they would cease to buy another cent worth.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: I went thru Armament School, was stationed at a training field and worked on the armament of planes for a month. Later my wife was to visit me and they were also short of a clerk, seeing that I had clerical experience before joining the Army, I accepted it because of the regular hours I was to have. I am on that same job for 7 months now and can't get anymore ratings. I tried to get reclassified to 502 (Clerk) but to no avail. Seeing that I have 4 years bookkeeping (over)
S64.Q97.C_1: experience I feel I should have the chance of being re-classified, if eleigible [eligible] , of course. [paragraph] I know I cost the government money by going thru Armament school but if this continues it will cost the government more. The duty I have don't seem important at all and I know I can be of more help to my country.
S64.Q97.Full: I went thru Armament School, was stationed at a training field and worked on the armament of planes for a month. Later my wife was to visit me and they were also short of a clerk, seeing that I had clerical experience before joining the Army, I accepted it because of the regular hours I was to have. I am on that same job for 7 months now and can't get anymore ratings. I tried to get reclassified to 502 (Clerk) but to no avail. Seeing that I have 4 years bookkeeping (over) experience I feel I should have the chance of being re-classified, if eleigible [eligible] , of course. [paragraph] I know I cost the government money by going thru Armament school but if this continues it will cost the government more. The duty I have don't seem important at all and I know I can be of more help to my country.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: I have ask for a discharge and have papers from the Red Cross oking it for dependence and I have not been given a fair chance on it. Have a defense Job waiting for me. I think a lot more are in my shoese and should be looked into by proper authorities. I thing the Army Air Corps should keep their word on passes and furloughs. Which they do not. They promise you everything when you join and give you nothing when.
S64.Q97.C_1: you get in. I think the drafter men get better deal than the enlisted men do. They get 7 days at first and furloughs and passes equally which we do not [deletion] ) [/deletion] get at all.
S64.Q97.Full: I have ask for a discharge and have papers from the Red Cross oking it for dependence and I have not been given a fair chance on it. Have a defense Job waiting for me. I think a lot more are in my shoese and should be looked into by proper authorities. I thing the Army Air Corps should keep their word on passes and furloughs. Which they do not. They promise you everything when you join and give you nothing when. you get in. I think the drafter men get better deal than the enlisted men do. They get 7 days at first and furloughs and passes equally which we do not [deletion] ) [/deletion] get at all.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: The army as a whole is like W.P.A. was too many men and not a thing to do for them but put in a lot of hours. That is for most of the men. Here we work 12 hrs a day 7 days a week and one pass a week. Some men don't do a thing but plant flowers I think that could wait untill after the war. [paragraph] A civilian war worker should get the same treatment a service man does.
S64.Q97.C_1: when he is AWOL [Absent Without Official Leave] after all we are human too and the kind of treatment is not the justice we are fighting for. The servicemen don't get any justice and the civilian does with it just as he pleases. We are at war and all in uniform weather a civilian or serviceman so why shouldn't we all be treated alike?
S64.Q97.Full: The army as a whole is like W.P.A. was too many men and not a thing to do for them but put in a lot of hours. That is for most of the men. Here we work 12 hrs a day 7 days a week and one pass a week. Some men don't do a thing but plant flowers I think that could wait untill after the war. [paragraph] A civilian war worker should get the same treatment a service man does.  when he is AWOL [Absent Without Official Leave] after all we are human too and the kind of treatment is not the justice we are fighting for. The servicemen don't get any justice and the civilian does with it just as he pleases. We are at war and all in uniform weather a civilian or serviceman so why shouldn't we all be treated alike?

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: I know the Army Classification has a big job but I would like to cite something that I think is important and should be remedied. [paragraph] The present A.S.T.P. [Army Specialized Training Program] calls for a great many qualified men - but I know of an instant where several men were accepted by a board for A.S.T.P. but when the letters of release were asked for the men were not released because
S64.Q97.C_1: of a claim that they were vital men. I know that these men are not vital and their jobs can be done by anyone capable of lifting (or even not capable) 50 pounds. I am sure that these men would be of far greater use to the Army and the country if they were put into this A.S.T.P. (Army Specialized Training Program). As I said before, classification is a big job, but that problem has recently come up and I think it is a very important one.
S64.Q97.Full: I know the Army Classification has a big job but I would like to cite something that I think is important and should be remedied. [paragraph] The present A.S.T.P. [Army Specialized Training Program] calls for a great many qualified men - but I know of an instant where several men were accepted by a board for A.S.T.P. but when the letters of release were asked for the men were not released because  of a claim that they were vital men. I know that these men are not vital and their jobs can be done by anyone capable of lifting (or even not capable) 50 pounds. I am sure that these men would be of far greater use to the Army and the country if they were put into this A.S.T.P. (Army Specialized Training Program). As I said before, classification is a big job, but that problem has recently come up and I think it is a very important one.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: I am a master machinist. I was taken from a vital war job. When I see store clerks or other untrained personnel in job which require the skill which I have and I know they haven't got, and I am doing a very menial job as a truck driver which I consider any moron could do, it seems to me the army classification system is haywire.
S64.Q97.Full: I am a master machinist. I was taken from a vital war job. When I see store clerks or other untrained personnel in job which require the skill which I have and I know they haven't got, and I am doing a very menial job as a truck driver which I consider any moron could do, it seems to me the army classification system is haywire.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: I think the army should let you choose what kind of work you are best fited [fitted] to do. Nine times out of ten the men do not get what they want, when it's left up to a classifier.
S64.Q97.Full: I think the army should let you choose what kind of work you are best fited [fitted] to do. Nine times out of ten the men do not get what they want, when it's left up to a classifier.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: I think that on the whole the army is run fairly well but there is entirely too much red tape and waste. The amount of food, [deletion] [/deletion] fuel and other necessities of war, that are wasted each day by the armed forces here in the States is enormous. The practice of [unclear] having [/unclear] such a large number of civilians at Army camps is another thing of which I do not approve. In a certain number of jobs there are [unclear] [/unclear] men that should be
S64.Q97.C_1: somewhere else. But in maintainence and repair shops, driving truck and other vehicles that are doing work that the [deletion] sold, sold [/deletion] soldier will have to do in combat. If he has to do it in combat I think he should do it in the training books to better prepare himself. A lot of the armys [deletion] falt [/deletion] faults apply to the civilian government also, i think that if the entire force of ideal [deletion] employ [/deletion] employees were cut in half, that the same amount of [deletion] a [/deletion] work could be done, more efficiently and at about half the cost.
S64.Q97.Full: I think that on the whole the army is run fairly well but there is entirely too much red tape and waste. The amount of food, [deletion] [/deletion] fuel and other necessities of war, that are wasted each day by the armed forces here in the States is enormous. The practice of [unclear] having [/unclear] such a large number of civilians at Army camps is another thing of which I do not approve. In a certain number of jobs there are [unclear] [/unclear] men that should be   somewhere else. But in maintainence and repair shops, driving truck and other vehicles that are doing work that the [deletion] sold, sold [/deletion] soldier will have to do in combat. If he has to do it in combat I think he should do it in the training books to better prepare himself. A lot of the armys [deletion] falt [/deletion] faults apply to the civilian government also, i think that if the entire force of ideal [deletion] employ [/deletion] employees were cut in half, that the same amount of [deletion] a [/deletion] work could be done, more efficiently and at about half the cost.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: I have been in the army almost 11 months and I think I should have had a furlough. They tell us that we can't get one for 3 more months, yet. We are the (so called) hand picked men of the Air Corps but fellows in all other branches get furloughs after about six months in the service. We can't get out of these schools and we can't get a furlough until we do. I think soldiers should have a furlough after finishing certain schools.
S64.Q97.C_1: Why does the army give a man a Sergeant rating [deletion] [/deletion] and then send him through a place like Salt Lake City, Utah and make him take orders from [deletion] [/deletion] Privates? If a man doesn't know enough about soldiering to be a Sergeant he shouldn't have the rating and if a Private knows enough about soldering to give orders to a non-commissioned officer he should have a rating.
S64.Q97.Full: I have been in the army almost 11 months and I think I should have had a furlough. They tell us that we can't get one for 3 more months, yet. We are the (so called) hand picked men of the Air Corps but fellows in all other branches get furloughs after about six months in the service. We can't get out of these schools and we can't get a furlough until we do. I think soldiers should have a furlough after finishing certain schools. Why does the army give a man a Sergeant rating [deletion] [/deletion] and then send him through a place like Salt Lake City, Utah and make him take orders from [deletion] [/deletion] Privates? If a man doesn't know enough about soldiering to be a Sergeant he shouldn't have the rating and if a Private knows enough about soldering to give orders to a non-commissioned officer he should have a rating.

Till I finally get to a outfit now we can't apply till we finish O.T.U. so it looks to me as if they don't want to give us one. Some of us boys haven't been home in about a year.
S64.Q97.C_1: And would like to visit our home very much

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: I think the army should give every man a furlough before he goes over seas. [paragraph] Sometimes the army takes too long to do a job, but considering everything they do a pretty good job. There is too many guys in the army that don't give a damn whether they work or not.
S64.Q97.Full: I think the army should give every man a furlough before he goes over seas. [paragraph] Sometimes the army takes too long to do a job, but considering everything they do a pretty good job. There is too many guys in the army that don't give a damn whether they work or not.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: I would certainly like to have a furlough. I have been in the army almost 10 months & haven't had a 3 day pass or furlough. My buddies who are in the army and enlisted or was drafted into the army since I enlisted, they have been home on furloughs. I can't see why ...
S64.Q97.C_1: all enlisted men in the U.S. Army can't be treated about the same as near as possible. Of course I realize this is war, but if other soldiers get them, why can't I & I have been going to schools from the East coast to teh West coast. The army must have the opinion that we fellows don't need to go home for a short time. This certainly doesn't seem like a very equal deal to me, and I am safe in saying several of my buddies feel the same way.
S64.Q97.Full: I would certainly like to have a furlough. I have been in the army almost 10 months & haven't had a 3 day pass or furlough. My buddies who are in the army and enlisted or was drafted into the army since I enlisted, they have been home on furloughs. I can't see why ... all enlisted men in the U.S. Army can't be treated about the same as near as possible. Of course I realize this is war, but if other soldiers get them, why can't I & I have been going to schools from the East coast to teh West coast. The army must have the opinion that we fellows don't need to go home for a short time. This certainly doesn't seem like a very equal deal to me, and I am safe in saying several of my buddies feel the same way.

S64.Q97.Full: I think men working on the line at this base should work only 8 hours a day instead of 12 hours a day for they have no time to relax.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: I would like to say only that I knew about what to expect when I gave up a college [unclear] career [/unclear] for the army - but [unclear] [/unclear] to now I have never [underline] really [/underline] had it as hard as I might have expected. There is only the [unclear] talking [/unclear] and complaining done by my buddies that make me think I'm not being treated
S64.Q97.C_1: as I should. But all in all, I believe that under the circumstances and conditions, the army is being run fairly well and efficiently, and I can see room for only a few minor improvements. [paragraph] But like I've said, I want to get over there where it's hot [underline] before [/underline] it cools off and then I doubt if I'll have any complaint left.
S64.Q97.Full: I would like to say only that I knew about what to expect when I gave up a college [unclear] career [/unclear] for the army - but [unclear] [/unclear] to now I have never [underline] really [/underline] had it as hard as I might have expected. There is only the [unclear] talking [/unclear] and complaining done by my buddies that make me think I'm not being treated  as I should. But all in all, I believe that under the circumstances and conditions, the army is being run fairly well and efficiently, and I can see room for only a few minor improvements. [paragraph] But like I've said, I want to get over there where it's hot [underline] before [/underline] it cools off and then I doubt if I'll have any complaint left.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: Furloughs in the air corp aren't given enough attention. If more attention was given then the morale would be very much higher.
S64.Q97.Full: Furloughs in the air corp aren't given enough attention. If more attention was given then the morale would be very much higher.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q96.M_marginalia: Things are a little worse, but that's to be expected in times like these.
S64.Q97.F: I guess it's an every day occurence for you to read thousands of these surveys and come across the same beef - that of furloughs! You probably get sick and tired of reading them & I can see your point. But suppose we look at the soldier's side of it. There are plenty of fellows just like me who joined the Army, not because they wanted to dodge the draft, but because they
S64.Q97.C_1: had the opportunity of selecting the branch of service that appealed to them. I chose the Air Corps. After 5 months of 42* below 0 weather at radio school, 8 weeks in a hot climate in Texas, 1 week in a place like Salt Lake where the discipline is absolutely unbearable. I came to a place where I thought sure I would get my furlough However, it will be necessary for me to finish 3 months or more of training before I can ever put in for one. Then if I'm lucky I'll get 7 days at home. Wonderful of them, I think. I live on the East coast, assigned to the west coast. On the whole, the air corps is very poorly run and I can think of many times when I could have had a furlough. I waited to start radio school 2 weeks. Gunnery - 3 weeks. Don't you think this time could be used to better advantage than putting us on K.P or squadron detail? the army would have soldiers of higher morals if they would only take a more personal interest in them. As for me - if I don't get my furlough, I'm one guy who's going over the hill for awhile!!!
S64.Q97.Full: I guess it's an every day occurence for you to read thousands of these surveys and come across the same beef - that of furloughs! You probably get sick and tired of reading them & I can see your point. But suppose we look at the soldier's side of it. There are plenty of fellows just like me who joined the Army, not because they wanted to dodge the draft, but because they had the opportunity of selecting the branch of service that appealed to them. I chose the Air Corps. After 5 months of 42* below 0 weather at radio school, 8 weeks in a hot climate in Texas, 1 week in a place like Salt Lake where the discipline is absolutely unbearable. I came to a place where I thought sure I would get my furlough However, it will be necessary for me to finish 3 months or more of training before I can ever put in for one. Then if I'm lucky I'll get 7 days at home. Wonderful of them, I think. I live on the East coast, assigned to the west coast. On the whole, the air corps is very poorly run and I can think of many times when I could have had a furlough. I waited to start radio school 2 weeks. Gunnery - 3 weeks. Don't you think this time could be used to better advantage than putting us on K.P or squadron detail? the army would have soldiers of higher morals if they would only take a more personal interest in them. As for me - if I don't get my furlough, I'm one guy who's going over the hill for awhile!!!

S64.Q97.F: Feel that the Selective Service system + the Army classification system are outmoded now + have been poorly administered most of the time. In my opinion there are large sections of continental Air Forces that are being very poorly administered - Air Forces policies are poorly conceived, thinly applied, + unstable. There is a tendency, particularly in the Air Corps, towards hit-or-miss + indifferent soldiering, + [insertion] lack [/insertion] [insertion] of [/insertion] uniformity in policy + administration [unclear] so [/unclear] there
S64.Q97.C_1: should be a return, + closer adhesion to, the old-line type of infantry soldiering, stabilization of policies + objectives, + strict hewing-to-the-line. [paragraph] Believe there should be more government sponsored efforts toward nation-wide, civilian participation in post-war thinking, planning, + actual construction along supervised lines. [paragraph] Feel also that strong-arm methods need to be asserted on the economic + production fronts + the war effort really prosecuted to an extend of perhaps 150 - 200% more than it is now - if it takes government control to do it, let's have it: the realization of a quickly-terminated war thru this means will easily enable the sound American public to forestall the possible evils of too much government control + power after the peace is won; it's complete prosecution of the war that is all-important now.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: I guess furloughs are an old coy in the army but I cant help but put my two cents in. The word furlough seems to be taboo in the Air Corps. So far I've been in over 9 months. In those nine months I havent even had an overnight pass. I havent been within 1,000 miles of home. Fellows that I knew in civilian life and are in other outfits have all ...
S64.Q97.C_1: gotten furloughs at the end of there first six month period. While I wouldn't want to be in any other outfit I think its very unfair that most of the fellows in the Air Corps never get a furlough. Right now I'm in O.T.U. [Operational Training Unit] with a vague promise of a furlough in a month or so. But theres a catch to it. I'm practically stationed on the West coast. My home is on the East coast. The furlough is only eight days including travelling time. That would just give me time to get home and turn around and come back. I know this piece won't do me much good but maybe it will do some good for the fellows following me.
S64.Q97.Full: I guess furloughs are an old coy in the army but I cant help but put my two cents in. The word furlough seems to be taboo in the Air Corps. So far I've been in over 9 months. In those nine months I havent even had an overnight pass. I havent been within 1,000 miles of home. Fellows that I knew in civilian life and are in other outfits have all ...  gotten furloughs at the end of there first six month period. While I wouldn't want to be in any other outfit I think its very unfair that most of the fellows in the Air Corps never get a furlough. Right now I'm in O.T.U. [Operational Training Unit] with a vague promise of a furlough in a month or so. But theres a catch to it. I'm practically stationed on the West coast. My home is on the East coast. The furlough is only eight days including travelling time. That would just give me time to get home and turn around and come back. I know this piece won't do me much good but maybe it will do some good for the fellows following me.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q95.M_marginalia: Do not want furloughs.
S64.Q97.F: I think we should stop all this paper work and get on the ball. And train men, not in to big a hurry. But do it harder then send them over. I have been in the Army for three year. After a man is in the Army over a year he does not
S64.Q97.C_1: do as much work as he does in the first six months of Army life. After he is trained to do his job its then just a job to him. The Army should be hard and stay that way. If you train a man hard, hes ready to go over, but if he is keep in the States a year or over after he is trained and doing the [unclear] time [/unclear] of war. He looses that hard Army life. He don't care to fight or he don't care if he does or not. He forgets what he fighting about. Thats why I think a man is best ready to fight within six months. Lets stop all this paper work, train and let us get this over with. We want to fight.
S64.Q97.Full: I think we should stop all this paper work and get on the ball. And train men, not in to big a hurry. But do it harder then send them over. I have been in the Army for three year. After a man is in the Army over a year he does not   do as much work as he does in the first six months of Army life. After he is trained to do his job its then just a job to him. The Army should be hard and stay that way. If you train a man hard, hes ready to go over, but if he is keep in the States a year or over after he is trained and doing the [unclear] time [/unclear] of war. He looses that hard Army life. He don't care to fight or he don't care if he does or not. He forgets what he fighting about. Thats why I think a man is best ready to fight within six months. Lets stop all this paper work, train and let us get this over with. We want to fight.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: Many of the fellows who came from college into the army were told before they left college that they would have the opportunity of [unclear] [/unclear] college under the Army Specialized Training Programs. Quite a few of us were accepted for the ASTP [Army Specialized Training Program] in Miami Beach 5 months ago. At our last base we were told that our records of acceptance were not forwarded and [unclear] [/unclear] we would not be able to apply again until one
S64.Q97.C_1: next base. This is our next base. Here we are told that the Post Commander has forbidden the post personnel to make applications for the A.S.T.P [Army Specialized Training Program] since too many men from this post were accepted and then sent back to the post. The army says it needs men for the ASTP. I think it should be more considerant in its policies. If it needs men why doesn't it use those men who are qualified? Can the Gowen Field [Boise Idaho, training Army Air Corps crews flying B-18 and B-26 bombers] C.O. [Commanding Officer] refuse applications for the ASTP to the personnel of the field?
S64.Q97.Full: Many of the fellows who came from college into the army were told before they left college that they would have the opportunity of [unclear] [/unclear] college under the Army Specialized Training Programs. Quite a few of us were accepted for the ASTP [Army Specialized Training Program] in Miami Beach 5 months ago. At our last base we were told that our records of acceptance were not forwarded and [unclear] [/unclear] we would not be able to apply again until one  next base. This is our next base. Here we are told that the Post Commander has forbidden the post personnel to make applications for the A.S.T.P [Army Specialized Training Program] since too many men from this post were accepted and then sent back to the post. The army says it needs men for the ASTP. I think it should be more considerant in its policies. If it needs men why doesn't it use those men who are qualified? Can the Gowen Field [Boise Idaho, training Army Air Corps crews flying B-18 and B-26 bombers] C.O. [Commanding Officer] refuse applications for the ASTP to the personnel of the field?

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q97.F: Operations would be much faster if it weren't for all red tape attached to everything. My job in the army is a mechanic and I feel that I could get more done if I didn't have to get a darn ??? signature on an order to draw the part I used. The men who sign for me don't know as to whether I need the part or not and I do.
S64.Q97.C_1: they always take my word for it anyway. [paragraph] There are a lot of men drafted into the army who shouldn't be here. Just now I saw a soldier who is deaf, wearing an ear phone. If his phone became broken what good would he be to his commander?
S64.Q97.Full: Operations would be much faster if it weren't for all red tape attached to everything. My job in the army is a mechanic and I feel that I could get more done if I didn't have to get a darn ??? signature on an order to draw the part I used. The men who sign for me don't know as to whether I need the part or not and I do. they always take my word for it anyway. [paragraph] There are a lot of men drafted into the army who shouldn't be here. Just now I saw a soldier who is deaf, wearing an ear phone. If his phone became broken what good would he be to his commander?

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q97.F: In my opinion this war is fought for money. If everyone were salaried the same we would all work a lot harder to get it over with. A certain race controls the finances and many businesses in this country and they do the least fighting. Many camps have them as permanent party while others do the fighting. Salt Lake City Utah is a fine example. Investigate it and find out who are in the majority in the permant party. In fact most camps
S64.Q97.C_1: are the same. We're not fighting to save their race we're fighting for democracy so as a true democracy we should all be in there fighting together. Also get some sound men in Washington. Instead of destroying sugar cane in La [Louisiana] then rationing sugar have it as we can get what we have. Instead of paying the farmer [underline] not [/underline] to raise feed or cattle let him go so we can feed the world which is going to be our job. Take the politicians out of Washington and put some men in there with brains.
S64.Q97.Full: In my opinion this war is fought for money. If everyone were salaried the same we would all work a lot harder to get it over with. A certain race controls the finances and many businesses in this country and they do the least fighting. Many camps have them as permanent party while others do the fighting. Salt Lake City Utah is a fine example. Investigate it and find out who are in the majority in the permant party. In fact most camps  are the same. We're not fighting to save their race we're fighting for democracy so as a true democracy we should all be in there fighting together. Also get some sound men in Washington. Instead of destroying sugar cane in La [Louisiana] then rationing sugar have it as we can get what we have. Instead of paying the farmer [underline] not [/underline] to raise feed or cattle let him go so we can feed the world which is going to be our job. Take the politicians out of Washington and put some men in there with brains.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: I think a soldier should get a furlough ever 6 mos, but most never do. I also think to much time is wasted. [paragraph] Why is it, that they put you into some work that you don't like + don't understand when you know something in another line very good + would like better?
S64.Q97.Full: I think a soldier should get a furlough ever 6 mos, but most never do. I also think to much time is wasted. [paragraph] Why is it, that they put you into some work that you don't like + don't understand when you know something in another line very good + would like better?

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: These Tech. schools are not run so good. They train you for one thing + usually put you on something else. They should give a man at least one furlough before going overseas especially after being in the army over a year There have been times in my army life that I could have gone home and not been missed just lay around + wait to start school yet no furlough +
S64.Q97.C_1: yet they knew all the time that I woulnt [wouldn't] start to school in two weeks. Dosent [doesn't] make sense to me.
S64.Q97.Full: These Tech. schools are not run so good. They train you for one thing + usually put you on something else. They should give a man at least one furlough before going overseas especially after being in the army over a year There have been times in my army life that I could have gone home and not been missed just lay around + wait to start school yet no furlough + yet they knew all the time that I woulnt [wouldn't] start to school in two weeks. Dosent [doesn't] make sense to me.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: I believe this to be more than just a war against the axis. They are only the things we are fighting, objectified. What we really fighting are the things they stand for. Tyranny, hate, destruction, cold-bloodedness, heartlessness, and the like. When this war is over our fight will have just begun. I only hope to God that it will
S64.Q97.C_1: have awakened people to the real fight. If it does it will not have been in vain, but gloriously worth while, and we can thank the enemy for showing us just what we must all fight. [paragraph] Ours is a battle first within ourselves, and then with all the things that the axis have so obligingly come to stand for. [paragraph] Until we have won that battle we will never never have peace.
S64.Q97.Full: I believe this to be more than just a war against the axis. They are only the things we are fighting, objectified. What we really fighting are the things they stand for. Tyranny, hate, destruction, cold-bloodedness, heartlessness, and the like. When this war is over our fight will have just begun. I only hope to God that it will have awakened people to the real fight. If it does it will not have been in vain, but gloriously worth while, and we can thank the enemy for showing us just what we must all fight. [paragraph] Ours is a battle first within ourselves, and then with all the things that the axis have so obligingly come to stand for. [paragraph] Until we have won that battle we will never never have peace.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: (Yes) I've been in this so called mans army about nine months. I've never seen more than an eight hour pass and that comes only once in a while. A three day pass is out of the question. If you try asking for a furlough they think your crazy. [paragraph] I have many a friends in the armed forces, and every last one of them have been home
S64.Q97.C_1: sometimes or other. Why can't the army give everyone an equal break, they can do it I know they can. [paragraph] I've laid around one time for a month, and a half in that time I could have been home twice, do you think they'd let you have a furlough (no) theyed let you stay somewhere down south and sweat it out doing absolutely nothing but eat, sleep and -----. I guess I should have been born a jew or with a name like Cohen.
S64.Q97.Full: (Yes) I've been in this so called mans army about nine months. I've never seen more than an eight hour pass and that comes only once in a while. A three day pass is out of the question. If you try asking for a furlough they think your crazy. [paragraph] I have many a friends in the armed forces, and every last one of them have been home  sometimes or other. Why can't the army give everyone an equal break, they can do it I know they can. [paragraph] I've laid around one time for a month, and a half in that time I could have been home twice, do you think they'd let you have a furlough (no) theyed let you stay somewhere down south and sweat it out doing absolutely nothing but eat, sleep and -----. I guess I should have been born a jew or with a name like Cohen.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q97.F: I have one personal gripe. I volunteered for active duty. When I first came into the army they sent me 3500 miles from home to a camp that the previous month was a Jap internment camp at Fresno California others what a lived in hotels down Alantic [Atlantic] City and Mimia [Miami] Beach Florida. Its unfair to the men being sent to different places like that. They should all be equal. I believe that a soldier should be sent to school and trained as close to his home as possible so he can be able to be home on weekends.
S64.Q97.C_1: when he goes home he wont have so much and another thing as a member of a flying crew I believe all flying men should be made officers we go up and risk our live as well as any other member of the crew in a bomber, no one is more independant on a flying mission we all need one another, why can't we be all graded and ranked equal when we are off the plane? [paragraph] In my statement that the Japs are very good fighters. I mean they are well trained but they are the dirtiest rottenest race of fighters I've ever heard and studyed [studied] . [paragraph] I believe that when the war is over we should have one train, if not by voluntary enlistment, by force. U.S. can be the strong man of the world. We should see that every thing is kept in order.
S64.Q97.Full: I have one personal gripe. I volunteered for active duty. When I first came into the army they sent me 3500 miles from home to a camp that the previous month was a Jap internment camp at Fresno California others what a lived in hotels down Alantic [Atlantic] City and Mimia [Miami] Beach Florida. Its unfair to the men being sent to different places like that. They should all be equal. I believe that a soldier should be sent to school and trained as close to his home as possible so he can be able to be home on weekends. when he goes home he wont have so much and another thing as a member of a flying crew I believe all flying men should be made officers we go up and risk our live as well as any other member of the crew in a bomber, no one is more independant on a flying mission we all need one another, why can't we be all graded and ranked equal when we are off the plane? [paragraph] In my statement that the Japs are very good fighters. I mean they are well trained but they are the dirtiest rottenest race of fighters I've ever heard and studyed [studied] . [paragraph] I believe that when the war is over we should have one train, if not by voluntary enlistment, by force. U.S. can be the strong man of the world. We should see that every thing is kept in order.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q97.F: Unnecessary waste of manpower, misplacement of men. Men are put into positions for which the are totally unsuited. I have seen it time and time again where for example they try to make an aerial gunner out of a man who has been a clerk all his life, who is not robust and not the slightest bit interested in gunnery. I've seen cases of where the Army would go to the expense of sending a man through school to make an air mechanic out of him
S64.Q97.C_1: and when he is finished school; sent to a sqdn. [squadron] he is made a radio man, or armor, [ armorer] or truck driver. All that education is wasted, all that time spent in learning is wasted, and he must proceed to start learning all over again. Schooling is wonderful, but unless what one has learned in theory, is used continually in everyday practice it is soon forgotten. One man well versed in what he is supposed to be doing is worth two poorly trained!!
S64.Q97.Full: Unnecessary waste of manpower, misplacement of men. Men are put into positions for which the are totally unsuited. I have seen it time and time again where for example they try to make an aerial gunner out of a man who has been a clerk all his life, who is not robust and not the slightest bit interested in gunnery. I've seen cases of where the Army would go to the expense of sending a man through school to make an air mechanic out of him  and when he is finished school; sent to a sqdn. [squadron] he is made a radio man, or armor, [ armorer] or truck driver. All that education is wasted, all that time spent in learning is wasted, and he must proceed to start learning all over again. Schooling is wonderful, but unless what one has learned in theory, is used continually in everyday practice it is soon forgotten. One man well versed in what he is supposed to be doing is worth two poorly trained!!

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: Yes, I have had my fair share of both furloughs and passes
S64.Q97.F: I believe a survey of this sort can mean a lot if followed through. There are questions in it that give a soldier a chance to "gripe". The men who do answer these questions are not just "griping", what they are doing is expressing themselves to someone whom they feel will do them somegood, for the first time since they have been in the army.
S64.Q97.Full: I believe a survey of this sort can mean a lot if followed through. There are questions in it that give a soldier a chance to "gripe". The men who do answer these questions are not just "griping", what they are doing is expressing themselves to someone whom they feel will do them somegood, for the first time since they have been in the army.

S64.Q97.F: Yes I think we should get a little more time on one furlough as some of us are so far to go home and when we get there we don't have much time for what it cost out to go home that it why I haven't ask for a furlough yet.
S64.Q97.Full: Yes I think we should get a little more time on one furlough as some of us are so far to go home and when we get there we don't have much time for what it cost out to go home that it why I haven't ask for a furlough yet.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: There are some questions I wasn't able to answer properly as I'm not in the branch of the service. About noncoms, I got all my stripes by attending army technical schools. I think we deserve them allright.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: No, I have not had my fair share of either furloughs or passes
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: In my outfit which is O.T.U. [Operational Training Unit] I have been averaging about five hours sleep a night. I work seven days a week. If you think that's not too rugged try it yourself sometime.
S64.Q97.Full: In my outfit which is O.T.U. [Operational Training Unit] I have been averaging about five hours sleep a night. I work seven days a week. If you think that's not too rugged try it yourself sometime.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97)
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: I've heard about too many fellows who are not given furloughs before they go overseas. Most of them don't mind risking their life, but they do want to get home. [paragraph] The laxity in training in the Air Force has been rectified a lot in the past year, but it could still stand improvement. Yes, I'm still in the opinion that a Radio mans Gunnery Course should be much longer
S64.Q97.Full: I've heard about too many fellows who are not given furloughs before they go overseas. Most of them don't mind risking their life, but they do want to get home. [paragraph] The laxity in training in the Air Force has been rectified a lot in the past year, but it could still stand improvement. Yes, I'm still in the opinion that a Radio mans Gunnery Course should be much longer

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: I Yes - I was flying with a B24 since the last of April - always on a per diem basis - so far I have only collected $1[underline] 50 [/underline] "because I was unassigned" - I come here to find cooks and the office men collecting - how the hell do you suppose that makes me feel - Well - maybe some day I'll get to know a Captain or a major too - [paragraph] II I was always of the opinion that officers
S64.Q97.C_1: well supposed to help out us dumb enlisted men -- not be out to break him such is was our case in B' him - Yes -- and I was connected with the [unclear] modif, [/unclear] groupe down there. Talk about shit huls
S64.Q97.Full: I Yes - I was flying with a B24 since the last of April - always on a per diem basis - so far I have only collected $1[underline] 50 [/underline] "because I was unassigned" - I come here to find cooks and the office men collecting - how the hell do you suppose that makes me feel - Well - maybe some day I'll get to know a Captain or a major too - [paragraph] II I was always of the opinion that officers well supposed to help out us dumb enlisted men -- not be out to break him such is was our case in B' him - Yes -- and I was connected with the [unclear] modif, [/unclear] groupe down there. Talk about shit huls

S64.Q96.M: Things are a little better, but not much
S64.Q97.F: I think the officers should get together & work together & be more [deletion] [/deletion] efitionate [efficient] & do more work instead of looking nice, & a Soldier should have anyway a 24 hr. [hour] pass once a week, or anyway when he asks for it.
S64.Q97.Full: I think the officers should get together & work together & be more [deletion] [/deletion] efitionate [efficient] & do more work instead of looking nice, & a Soldier should have anyway a 24 hr. [hour] pass once a week, or anyway when he asks for it.

document_type: A document that contains three questions (Q.95, Q.96 and Q.97), A continuation page
S64.Q95.M: I have had my fair share of passes but not furloughs
S64.Q97.F: There are officers who don't give up a chance to get ahead. Some officers like to have their boots licked and if we don't, you are out. Some are nice fellows but some are really piss-poor. It would really be a nice thing if you, who are reading these over, did some of the things that the fellows that have been in the
S64.Q97.C_1: army quit awhile write in these. They know how army life is. So far I've found out its not what you know, its who you know. There are Pvt. who could run this army a lot better than some of our, so called, Brass Hats. I could write all day but whats the use. No army is perfect -
S64.Q97.Full: There are officers who don't give up a chance to get ahead. Some officers like to have their boots licked and if we don't, you are out. Some are nice fellows but some are really piss-poor. It would really be a nice thing if you, who are reading these over, did some of the things that the fellows that have been in the  army quit awhile write in these. They know how army life is. So far I've found out its not what you know, its who you know. There are Pvt. who could run this army a lot better than some of our, so called, Brass Hats. I could write all day but whats the use. No army is perfect -
